subject: Re: How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... I m not sure where the statistical cut-off point would be. I ll have to take your word for it that if 60% (or more) of the code in a class is private
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Michael Feathers <mfeathers@m...> wrote:

> The issue is that when it is hard to test something without tricks
> (like reflective access) it usually means that there is a design
> with better cohesion out there to discover. I'd say that if 60% of
> your logic is in private methods, then chances are very high that
> this is true for that code.
>
> Michael Feathers
> www.objectmentor.com

I'm not sure where the statistical cut-off point would be. I'll have
to take your word for it that if 60% (or more) of the code in a class
is private implementation then there is reason for suspicion. I know
that if you just count LOC in some of my code that the private
implementation percentage will likely be high. The reason for this, I
think, is that I tend to refactor agressively, extracting methods
whenever I can give even a code fragment (like the test of an if) a
good intention-revealing name.

Has anyone suggested the use of code coverage metrics as a way to
quell the gotta-testa-private syndrome? When practicing TDD I have
found that private methods really only arise from refactoring of less
restrictively scoped methods. Since extracting a method is really just
moving code within the class, if the code had 100% coverage before the
test it should still have 100% coverage after the test. Are any of the
open source / free code coverage tools particularly worth
recommending?
http://java-source.net/open-source/code-coverage

Jim
